content.description: What appears to be Aqueduct'Â’s most recent addition, and possibly its shortest route, is surprisingly good.  It climbs one of the blanker expanses of rock on the crag via some of the most powerful moves Aqueduct has to offer.
content.protection: Draws.  May want a hand-size cam to protect the moves to the first bolt.  Chains on top.
content.location:
Look for a 3-bolt line left of

Submachine's

bolts (and

Dredging the Trench

).  For the location of

Submachine

, refer to TP's excellent photo-topo on the main page for the crag.

climbs.name: Terra Nova
climbs.fa: Bret, Stuart Ruckman, and Gary Olsen 1985

content.description: A beatiful line, past an intimidating roof, onto a face that is harder than any of the routes on the SW face.  The roof is not as hard as it looks, and pulling the lip is exciting.  The face above will offer the most resistance, especially for the shorter folks.  Finally after the face, a leftward trending traverse below the big roof will get you to the anchors.
content.protection: 1 bolt on the route with a fixed nut as backup.  The bolt is bad.  The roof can be protected well, but you may lose your handholds if you sew it up.  The face above has sparser protection but should be ok.  Small to medium gear for most of the route, maybe a few larger nuts or cams for the travese.
content.location: Right of Aquaduck, through the obvious and deep roof, on the SW face.

content.description: This is the right bolted line on the SE face.  It is steep and pumpy and has a smooth bulge that bewilders.
content.protection: 2 anchors at the top.  I believe 4 bolts on the way to the top.  Some small gear could help take a bite out of the runout.

content.description: On the SW face, left of the big roof is a rotten-looking (but solid) white looking face.  There are 2 routes that are bolted here.  This is the left one.  Climb up the crack to attain the ledge where one can clip the first bolt.  Continue up this steep face to the chains.  Lots of crimpers, and good footwork.  With only the occasional reachy move.  Good workout.
content.protection: 2 bolts are at the top for anchors, and 4-6 draws for the climb.  A small selection of medium gear will protect the moves up to the ledge.

content.description: This is the face between Sockdollager and Straight Talk (The two rightmost cracks on the SE face).  Climb the slightly inverted face on thin holds, meeting up with Straight Talk at the end.
content.protection: 2 draws for the chain anchors, shared with Sockdollager and Straight Talk. No Protection.

content.description: The furthest right crack on the south-east face.  This crack is steep but the jams are all there.  Near the top there is a hole, at that point, angle left across the face to the chains.  This is just after the crux.
content.protection: 2 draws for the chains set a decent anchor, although they create a pendulum.  They can be attained by traversing along a small sloping ledge.  To lead it bring a standard rack.

content.description: This climbs the crack directly above the large boulder.  Step off and balance your way to the beginning of the climb.  This climb has nice finger and hand jams and the occasional layback.
content.protection: 2 anchors atop the climb make for an easy top-rope. However, it also protects well with standard rack.  Larger nuts worked well.

content.description: A new climb, this route climbs like it's neighbors, with one exception:  It has an arete to use.  Solid rock, steep climbing, with good edges and a lot of sidepulls, except for the finish (which still isn't runout), and great exposure.
content.location: Just left of Aquaduck, but right of Burning Bits and Submachine, on the SW face.

content.description: This is the left bolted line on the SE face.  The beginning is bouldery, but small nuts protect the initial moves well.  It eases up with widely spaced bolts, so bring extra gear. This shares the anchors with Subterrainian and Double Standard, and is the quickest way to set up a toprope for those 2 climbs.
content.protection: 2 draws for anchors.  4 draws on the way and a small selection of small to medium nuts.

content.description: Spot the grey hanger, the route is here. Just to the left of Lip Service. Weird traversing with a lip sequence that involves a palm.
content.protection: QD's, maybe a sling or two, #0 metolius to #4 metolius (supplemental gear not a must)
content.location: As you step around from the south face to the east face there is a gap. Just on the right hand side of the gap/cleft is a overhang. The route starts with a "no foot start".

content.description: Dredge your way up the chosy, scaly, mineral deposited, vegetated  crack to the left of Submachine.
content.protection: Cams to 2"-3".  If you clip bolts to the right of the crack you are on Submachine.

content.description: Just left of the large boulder, is a crack that requires stemming down low and jams the rest of the way.  The protection is there and the moves are not too bad.
content.protection: 2 bolts are at the top for anchors.  Getting to the anchors requires a lead of some sort.  If one doesn't feel like leading a trad route, one can lead Lip Service.

content.description: From the road, one can see a polished east face, on the right side of the wall. This climbs the left side of it. Broken rock and poor aesthetics.
content.protection: Standard rack, and slings around a concrete block for the anchor.

content.description: From the road, one can see a polished east face, on the right side of the wall.  This climbs the right side of it.  It starts off with some broken rock, and a couple of bulges, and ends up with a nice polished quartzite exit.
content.protection: Small to medium gear, and the anchor can be a concrete aquaduct foundation wrapped with slings.

content.description: This route is on the SW face, left of the big roof there is a rotten "looking" section of rock with mineral residue from the aquaduct.  Two new routes climb this rock, this is the right-most.  This looks rotten but is solid, with nice crimpers and a nice angle. This is a pumping climb that works a couple of small roofs.  Nice line.
content.protection: 2 draws for the chains atop the cliff.  Plus 5?? draws for the bolts on the way up.  Maybe a small selection of medium nuts to protect the inital moves

content.description: Face climb on edges through fractures and broken cracks with great feet.  Placing gear is a little pumpy.  Don't get sucked left - head up and a little right, intersecting the little roof on the right.  Seems like you wind up placing gear at your chest/waist a lot.
content.protection: TCU's or aliens and cam's to #2 camalot.  A double set of smaller gear is nice.  You don't really need all of them, but the options are nice. You have to nail the gear but its all there and better than you think when you're standing on the ledge getting psyched to commit to starting.  A proud, very worthy line.
